messageBody:
On 0, james.dobson@... wrote:

Hello,

IMHO, Your problem can be solved using Abstract Test pattern.
You can create a class with all your tests with an abstract method:

class AbstractBaseTestClass
protected JTextComponent getTestedTextComponent();

public void setUp()
{
this.component = getTestedTextComponent();
}


Then you make two subclasses of your abstract class, where you
implement this method:

TestClassA extend AbstractBaseTestClass
protected JTextComponent getTestedTextComponent()
{
return new ChildA();
}

TestClassB extend AbstractBaseTestClass
protected JTextComponent getTestedTextComponent()
{
return new ChildB();
}

As far as both TestClassA and TestClassB contain the same set of
tests (they inherit them from parent), you'll test both components.

Regards,
KIR

> In my situation I have a test MyTest that runs a number of tests against a
> JTextComponent. ChildA and ChildB are types of JTextComponent and do not

> MyTest can test these different subclasses of JTextComponent.

> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: james.dobson@... [mailto:james.dobson@...]
> > Sent: woensdag 7 augustus 2002 12:27
> > To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> > Subject: [junit]

> >
> > Hi Everyone,
> >
> > Is it possible to automatically add all the tests of a test
> > class to a suite
> > without using 'suite.addTestSuite(MyTest.class)'?
> >
> > I have a test class that can test a number of classes from the same
> > hierarchy. Let's say for arguments sake that I have created two child
> > classes (ChildA and ChildB) of type JTextComponent and both
> > of them override
> > a number of methods such as setText. I have a number of
> > tests that test the
> > newly overridden methods. I have created a constructor for
> > the class that
> > looks something like this:
> >
> > public MyTest(String name, JTextComponent component)
> > {
> > super(name);
> > this.component = component;
> > }
> >
> > My problem is this: I want to run this test twice, once for
> > childA and once
> > for childB. But I don't want to type in the tests individually e.g.
> >
> > public class MyTestClient
> > {
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> > ChildA()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> > ChildA()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> > ChildA()));
> > ........
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> > ChildA()));
> >
> > // Then the same for childB
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test1", new
> > ChildB()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test2", new
> > ChildB()));
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("test3", new
> > ChildB()));
> > ........
> > suite.addTest(new MyTest("testN", new
> > ChildB()));
> > return suite;
> > }
> > public static void main(String[] args)
> > {
> > junit.swingui.TestRunner.run(MyTestClient.class);
> > }
> > }
> >
> > How I would like to write the suite method is something like this:
> >
> > public static Test suite()
> > {
> > TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> >
> > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here
> > to indicate I
> > want to test ChildA */)
> > suite.addTest(MyTest.class /** Parameter here
> > to indicate I
> > want to test ChildB */)
> > }
> >
> > Hope this is a sensible question!
> >
> > James
